summary: This is an email chain from October 2020 regarding forensic examination of devices seized in the Epstein case. An Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York follows up with a forensic examiner about missing image and video files from specific devices, indicating an ongoing evidence review process.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of the email, inquiring about the status of image and video file extraction from specific Epstein case devices.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: The recipient of the email, addressed regarding the status of forensic image and video extraction from seized devices.

connections.person1: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Prosecutor communicating with a forensic examiner regarding evidence handling in the Epstein case.

events.title: Evidence Drop-off and Initial Review
events.description: Forensic image and video files from Epstein devices were dropped off to the prosecutor, who conducted an initial review and found one device folder empty.
personsInvolved: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

keyFacts: The email discusses forensic image and video files extracted from devices seized in the Epstein investigation.
Device NYC024342 was found to have empty folders, indicating a potential issue with data extraction or transfer.
Multiple other devices (NYC024328, NYC024329, NYC024353, NYC024365, NYC024366, NYC024371, NYC024383) were listed as still pending for image and video file delivery.
The correspondence is subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence.
The communication shows active evidence review by the prosecution in October 2020, years after Epstein's arrest and death.
